name: Elise Meitner
quote: Science makes people reach selflessly for truth and objectivity; it teaches people to accept reality, with wonder and admiration, not to mention the deep awe and joy that the natural order of things brings to the true scientist.
summary: Austrian physicist who made groundbreaking contributions to nuclear physics and was part of the team that discovered nuclear fission.
shortDescription: Elise Meitner was an Austrian physicist who made groundbreaking contributions to nuclear physics. She was part of the team that discovered nuclear fission and was the first to explain the process theoretically. Despite being overlooked for the Nobel Prize, her work laid the foundation for nuclear energy and modern physics.

detailed_description.early_life: Born in 1878 in Vienna, Austria, Elise showed exceptional talent in mathematics and physics from an early age. She was one of the first women to earn a PhD in physics from the University of Vienna.
detailed_description.stem_journey: Elise began her career working with Otto Hahn in Berlin, where they made significant discoveries in radioactivity. She became one of the leading experts in nuclear physics and was the first woman to become a full professor of physics in Germany.
detailed_description.challenges: As a Jewish woman in Nazi Germany, Elise faced discrimination and persecution. She was forced to flee Germany in 1938 and lost her research position. She was also overlooked for the Nobel Prize despite her crucial contributions.
detailed_description.achievements: Elise made groundbreaking contributions to nuclear physics, including the discovery of nuclear fission. She was the first to explain the process theoretically and made numerous discoveries in radioactivity.
detailed_description.legacy: Elise's work laid the foundation for nuclear energy and modern physics. She is considered one of the most important physicists of the 20th century, and element 109 (meitnerium) is named in her honor.
